notes: Questions 151-300 for GCSE Computer Science (UK) — Computer Systems & Theory. Designed to follow first 150 and broaden coverage.

questions.stem: How many bits are in 1 byte?
questions.explanation: A byte is made of 8 bits.

questions.stem: What does 'LSB' stand for in binary?
questions.explanation: LSB means Least Significant Bit—the rightmost bit in a binary number.

questions.stem: What does 'MSB' stand for in binary?
questions.explanation: MSB means Most Significant Bit—the leftmost bit in a binary number.

questions.stem: How many values can 7 bits represent?
questions.explanation: n bits represent 2^n values. 2^7 = 128 values.

questions.stem: How many different values can 1 byte represent?
questions.explanation: 1 byte = 8 bits, so it represents 2^8 = 256 values.

questions.stem: What is 1010 in denary (base 10)?
What is 1100 in denary (base 10)?
What is 0111 in denary (base 10)?
What is 1001 in denary (base 10)?
What is 1111 in denary (base 10)?
What is 0101 in denary (base 10)?
What is 13 in 8-bit binary?
What is 6 in 8-bit binary?
What is 9 in 8-bit binary?
What is 20 in 8-bit binary?
In hexadecimal, what value does 'A' represent?
In hexadecimal, what value does 'F' represent?
questions.explanation: In hex, F represents 15.

questions.stem: Why is hex convenient for representing binary?
options: One hex digit represents exactly 4 bits
questions.explanation: Hex maps neatly to binary: 4 bits (a nibble) per hex digit.

questions.stem: What is binary 1111 in hexadecimal?
questions.explanation: 1111₂ = 15₁₀ = F₁₆.

questions.stem: What is binary 1010 in hexadecimal?
questions.explanation: 1010₂ = 10₁₀ = A₁₆.

questions.stem: What is hexadecimal 1C in binary?
What is hexadecimal 2F in binary?
What is hexadecimal 0A in binary?
What is overflow in binary?
options: When an image has too many colours
When a binary value is too large to fit in the available bits
When packets arrive out of order
questions.explanation: Overflow happens when the result needs more bits than are available, causing wraparound/loss of the leading bit.

questions.stem: Add 00001111 and 00000001 (8-bit). What is the result?
questions.explanation: 15 + 1 = 16, which is 00010000 in 8-bit binary.

questions.stem: In 4-bit unsigned binary, what happens when you add 1111 and 0001?
questions.explanation: 4-bit unsigned max is 15 (1111). 15+1=16 needs 5 bits, so it overflows and wraps to 0000.

questions.stem: What does 'resolution' refer to in a bitmap image?
questions.explanation: Resolution is the number of pixels used to form the image, usually width × height.

questions.stem: Colour depth describes…
options: How many pixels the image has
How many bits are used per pixel
How many times the image is sampled per second
questions.explanation: Colour depth is bits per pixel; more bits allow more colours.

questions.stem: An image is 200×100 pixels with 1-bit colour depth. Minimum size (bytes)?
An image is 80×60 pixels with 8-bit colour depth. Minimum size (bytes)?
If colour depth is increased from 8-bit to 16-bit, what happens to uncompressed file size (same resolution)?
questions.explanation: Doubling bits per pixel roughly doubles the uncompressed data size.

questions.stem: Sampling rate is…
questions.explanation: Sampling rate is how many samples are taken each second, measured in Hz.

questions.stem: Bit depth in audio affects…
options: How many amplitude values are possible per sample
questions.explanation: Higher bit depth allows more amplitude levels (better quality) but increases file size.

questions.stem: Stereo audio means…
questions.explanation: Stereo uses two channels (left and right).

questions.stem: Audio sampled at 10,000 Hz, 8-bit, mono, 5 seconds. Size (bytes)?
questions.explanation: Samples=10,000×5=50,000. 8-bit=1 byte. Mono=1 channel → 50,000 bytes.

questions.stem: If you double the sampling rate (same duration/bit depth/channels), file size…
questions.explanation: Doubling sampling rate doubles the number of samples, so file size doubles.

questions.stem: Run-length encoding (RLE) works best when…
options: Data is random with no repetition
There are long runs of repeated values
questions.explanation: RLE is most effective when data contains repeated sequences (e.g., large areas of the same colour).

questions.stem: Which file type is most commonly lossy?
questions.explanation: JPEG is a lossy image compression format. PNG and ZIP are lossless.

questions.stem: What is a NIC used for?
options: To connect a device to a network
questions.explanation: A Network Interface Card allows a device to connect to a network.

questions.stem: Which topology uses a central device (like a switch) that all nodes connect to?
questions.explanation: Star topology uses a central switch/hub device.

questions.stem: One advantage of star topology is…
options: A break in one cable breaks the whole network
Easy to add/remove devices and faults are isolated
questions.explanation: In star, each device has its own connection, so faults can be isolated.

questions.stem: One disadvantage of star topology is…
options: If the central switch fails, the network can stop
It is always slower than bus
questions.explanation: The central device is a single point of failure.

questions.stem: A modem is mainly used to…
options: Convert signals to connect to an ISP line
questions.explanation: A modem modulates/demodulates signals for certain internet connections.

questions.stem: Which measure is typically in bits per second?
questions.explanation: Bandwidth is measured in bits per second (bps).

questions.stem: High latency is most noticeable as…
questions.explanation: Latency is the delay; high latency feels like lag.

questions.stem: Why can packets arrive out of order?
options: Packets can take different routes with different delays
questions.explanation: Different routes and congestion can cause varying delays, so packets may arrive out of order.

questions.stem: Which is the best description of DNS?
options: A system that translates domain names to IP addresses
questions.explanation: DNS maps human-readable domain names to numeric IP addresses.

questions.stem: Packet switching improves reliability because…
options: If one route fails, packets can be rerouted
questions.explanation: Packets can be rerouted around failures or congestion.

questions.stem: A MAC address is mainly used…
options: Within a LAN for switching frames to the right device
questions.explanation: Switches use MAC addresses to forward frames within a local network.

questions.stem: Which protocol is used for secure web browsing?
questions.explanation: HTTPS is the secure version of HTTP using TLS encryption.

questions.stem: Which layer of TCP/IP deals with reliable delivery?
questions.explanation: The transport layer (TCP) provides reliability, acknowledgements and retransmissions.

questions.stem: Which protocol is typically used to receive email (not send)?
questions.explanation: IMAP or POP3 are used to retrieve emails; SMTP is used to send.

questions.stem: Why might UDP be chosen over TCP for online gaming?
options: UDP has lower overhead and lower latency
questions.explanation: Games often prioritise low latency; occasional loss is acceptable.

questions.stem: What is the main job of IP in networking?
questions.explanation: IP handles addressing and routing across networks.

questions.stem: Which OS feature allows multiple programs to appear to run at once on a single-core CPU?
questions.explanation: Time slicing rapidly switches CPU time between processes so it appears simultaneous.

questions.stem: What is the purpose of a file system?
options: To organise how files are stored and retrieved
questions.explanation: A file system organises data on storage (folders, names, allocation).

questions.stem: Which component loads the operating system at boot?
questions.explanation: Firmware in ROM starts the boot process and loads the OS.

questions.stem: Why does defragmentation help some HDDs but not SSDs?
options: HDDs have moving heads so contiguous data can reduce seek time
questions.explanation: HDDs have seek time; SSDs have near-uniform access so defrag is less useful.

questions.stem: What is a common role of the OS device manager?
questions.explanation: Device management uses drivers so the OS can control hardware.

questions.stem: What does it mean when a process is 'swapped out'?
options: Moved from RAM to storage temporarily
questions.explanation: Swapping moves inactive data from RAM to storage (virtual memory) to free RAM.

questions.stem: Which is a likely symptom of too little RAM?
options: Frequent disk activity and slowdown when multitasking
questions.explanation: Low RAM can cause swapping to disk, making the system slow.

questions.stem: Which threat involves software that locks your files and demands payment?
questions.explanation: Ransomware encrypts or locks files and demands payment.

questions.stem: Which is the BEST defence against malware infection from downloads?
options: Use reputable sources + antivirus + keep software updated
questions.explanation: Combining safe behaviour with antivirus and updates reduces malware risk.

questions.stem: What is a keylogger?
questions.explanation: Keyloggers capture typed keys to steal credentials.

questions.stem: Why is using the same password on many sites risky?
options: If one site is breached, attackers can try the same credentials elsewhere
questions.explanation: Credential reuse allows attackers to access multiple accounts after one breach.

questions.stem: Which is an example of physical security?
questions.explanation: Physical security controls access to hardware and locations.

questions.stem: Social engineering mainly exploits…
questions.explanation: It targets people (e.g., persuasion, urgency) rather than technical flaws.

questions.stem: Which is a likely ethical concern with facial recognition in public spaces?
options: It may invade privacy and enable surveillance
questions.explanation: Ethical concerns include privacy, consent, and misuse of identification data.

questions.stem: Why is e-waste a problem?
options: It can contain toxic materials and creates pollution if not handled properly
questions.explanation: E-waste contains harmful materials; unsafe disposal harms the environment and people.

questions.stem: What does 'consent' mean in data protection?
options: User agrees to data collection/processing after being informed
questions.explanation: Consent means users agree after understanding what data is collected and why.

questions.stem: Which is an example of copyright infringement?
options: Copying and distributing paid software without permission
questions.explanation: Copying/distributing copyrighted software without permission breaches copyright.

questions.stem: What is the purpose of HTTP?
questions.explanation: HTTP is the protocol used for web requests and responses.

questions.stem: Which device forwards data based on IP addresses?
questions.explanation: Routers forward packets between networks using IP addresses.

questions.stem: Which memory is fastest?
questions.explanation: Registers are the fastest storage locations (inside the CPU).

questions.stem: Why do organisations use servers in client-server networks?
options: For centralised control, security, and backups
To remove the need for routers
questions.explanation: Servers centralise resources and policies, making management and security easier.

questions.stem: Which device forwards data based on IP addresses?
questions.explanation: Routers forward packets between networks using IP addresses.

questions.stem: Which component is responsible for decoding instructions and issuing control signals?
questions.explanation: The Control Unit decodes instructions and controls the CPU.

questions.stem: Which device forwards data based on IP addresses?
questions.explanation: Routers forward packets between networks using IP addresses.

questions.stem: Why is encryption not the same as backup?
options: Encryption protects confidentiality; backup protects against loss
questions.explanation: Encryption keeps data private; backups allow recovery if data is lost or damaged.

questions.stem: Why might a mesh topology be very reliable?
options: There are multiple paths between devices
questions.explanation: Multiple connections provide redundancy if one link fails.

questions.stem: A school collects student fingerprints for lunch payments. Main concern?
options: Sensitive biometric data privacy and security
questions.explanation: Biometric data is sensitive; it requires strong security and clear purpose/consent.

questions.stem: Which device forwards data based on MAC addresses within a LAN?
questions.explanation: Switches forward frames within a LAN using MAC addresses.

questions.stem: What does 'availability' mean in security?
options: Systems and data are accessible when needed
questions.explanation: Availability means services/data are accessible to authorised users when required.

questions.stem: A 'bitmap' image is made of…
questions.explanation: Bitmap images store colour values for each pixel in a grid.

questions.stem: What does 'confidentiality' mean in security?
options: Only authorised users can access data
questions.explanation: Confidentiality means preventing unauthorised access to data.

questions.stem: Which is an OS responsibility?
questions.explanation: The OS manages resources like memory, processes, devices and files.

questions.stem: What is the purpose of HTTP?
questions.explanation: HTTP is the protocol used for web requests and responses.

questions.stem: A school collects student fingerprints for lunch payments. Main concern?
options: Sensitive biometric data privacy and security
questions.explanation: Biometric data is sensitive; it requires strong security and clear purpose/consent.

questions.stem: What is the purpose of HTTP?
questions.explanation: HTTP is the protocol used for web requests and responses.

questions.stem: Which memory is fastest?
questions.explanation: Registers are the fastest storage locations (inside the CPU).

questions.stem: A student can't load websites but can still ping an IP address. Most likely issue?
questions.explanation: If IP connectivity works but domain names fail, DNS is likely the issue.

questions.stem: What does 'availability' mean in security?
options: Systems and data are accessible when needed
questions.explanation: Availability means services/data are accessible to authorised users when required.

questions.stem: Which memory is fastest?
questions.explanation: Registers are the fastest storage locations (inside the CPU).

questions.stem: An image is 64×64 pixels, colour depth 1 bit. Minimum size (bytes)?
questions.explanation: Pixels=4096. Bits=4096×1=4096 bits. Bytes=4096÷8=512 bytes.

questions.explanation: Registers are the fastest storage locations (inside the CPU).

questions.stem: What does 'integrity' mean in security?
options: Data remains accurate and not altered without permission
questions.explanation: Integrity is about data being correct and protected from unauthorised changes.

options: Data remains accurate and not altered without permission
questions.explanation: Integrity is about data being correct and protected from unauthorised changes.

questions.stem: Why can adding more RAM improve performance?
options: It reduces swapping to virtual memory on storage
questions.explanation: More RAM reduces the need for slow virtual memory swapping.

options: It reduces swapping to virtual memory on storage
questions.explanation: More RAM reduces the need for slow virtual memory swapping.

questions.stem: Why does the OS use permissions (read/write/execute)?
options: To control who can access or modify files/programs
questions.explanation: Permissions help protect data and enforce security and user control.

questions.stem: A user is tricked into installing fake 'antivirus' software. This is most likely…
questions.explanation: Fake security software is a common trojan tactic—disguised as legitimate.

questions.stem: Which device forwards data based on IP addresses?
questions.explanation: Routers forward packets between networks using IP addresses.

questions.stem: Which is a key advantage of SSDs over HDDs?
questions.explanation: SSDs use flash memory and have faster access with better durability.
